title: 104_s1819
content: The Act is titled the "Retirement Savings and Security Act" and includes a table of contents. It also addresses conforming railroad retirement benefits with Social Security. The Retirement Savings and Security Act includes provisions for child's annuity, spousal annuities, survivor benefits, lump sum death benefits, and payment equivalent to social security benefits for certain railroad retirement annuities. Effective date is also specified. The Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 is amended to include eligibility criteria for a child's annuity, specifying conditions such as age, student status, disability, and dependency on the employee. The Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 is amended to include eligibility criteria for a child's annuity, specifying conditions such as age, student status, disability, and dependency on the employee. An employee shall be entitled to an annuity under specified conditions, with the amount determined based on the individual's service history and any benefits payable under the Social Security Act. Amendments also include technical changes to include the spouse, child, and divorced wife in certain sections of the Act. SEC. 2002. ENTITLEMENT TO SPOUSAL ANNUITIES. Amendments to the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 include entitlement for spouses meeting conditions for annuity despite age requirements and removal of age requirement for divorced spouses who have completed 10 years of service. Amendment to the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 allows entitlement for spouses who have completed 10 years of service, removing age requirements for divorced spouses. SEC. 2003. Continued payment to survivors of waived lump sum benefits equivalent to Social Security survivor benefits. Section 6(c)(1) of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 is amended to require an irrevocable election by the widow, widower, or parent of a deceased employee to receive a lump sum payment in lieu of other benefits. Once this election is made and the lump sum is paid, no further benefits will be provided, except for Social Security survivor benefits. No additional benefits will be paid under the Railroad Retirement Act after a lump sum payment is received, except for Social Security survivor benefits. SEC. 2004 of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 is amended to provide lump-sum death benefits equivalent to Social Security benefits for individuals with ten years of service in the railroad industry at the time of their death. This payment is in accordance with the Social Security Act and will be deducted from any other benefits received under the Railroad Retirement Act. SEC. 2005 amends the Railroad Retirement Act to provide annuities equivalent to Social Security benefits for individuals whose annuities are not payable due to specific reasons. The annuity amount will be the difference between the Social Security benefit paid and what would have been paid if all service after December 31, 1936, had been included in the calculation. The amendments made by SEC. 2005 provide annuities equivalent to Social Security benefits for individuals with specific reasons. SEC. 2006 states that these amendments will take effect on January 1, 1997.
